contentrichtext.text: {{about||the mountain on the border of Chile and Bolivia in the Potosí Department, Daniel Campos Province|Iru Phutunqu (Chile-Daniel Campos)}} {{Infobox mountain | name = Iru Phutunqu | photo = | photo_caption = | elevation_m = 5163 | elevation_ref = <ref name=gvp>{{cite gvp|vnum=1505-04=|title=Irruputuncu|accessdate=2004-12-28}}</ref> | prominence_m = | prominence_ref= | location = [[Bolivia]]-[[Chile]]<br>[[Potosí Department]], [[Nor Lípez Province]]<br> [[Tarapacá Region]] | range = [[Andes]], [[Cordillera Occidental (Bolivia)|Cordillera Occidental]] | map = Bolivia | region =BO | label_position = right | map_size = 200 | lat_d =20|lat_m =43|lat_s =55|lat_NS =S | long_d=68|long_m=33|long_s=08|long_EW=W | coordinates_ref= | source = GNS-enwiki | type = [[Stratovolcano]] | age = | last_eruption = 1995<ref name=gvp/> | first_ascent = | easiest_route = }} [[File:Sf-19-3-cerro paruma-bolivia-chile-1999.pdf|thumb|right|250px|Map showing Iru Phutunqu on the border of Bolivia and Chile south west of the Uyuni salt flat]] '''Iru Phutunqu''' ([[Aymara language|Aymara]] ''iru'' spiny [[Peruvian feather grass]], ''phutunqu'' a small vessel or a hole, pit, crater,<ref>Ludovico Bertonio, Kastilla-Aymara simi qullqa: '''''Iru.''''' - ''Ichu espinoso.'' '''''Phutunqu.''''' - ''Un vasito de barro o redoma.'' '''''Phutunqu''''' ''vel'' '''''Phujru.''''' - ''Hoyo de la tierra sin agua, no muy hondo.''</ref> hispanicized spellings ''Iru Putuncu, Irruputuncu, Iruputuncu'') is a [[stratovolcano]] which lies on the border of [[Chile]] and [[Bolivia]]. On the Chilean side it is situated in the [[Tarapacá Region]]. On the Bolivian side it is located in the [[Potosí Department]], [[Nor Lípez Province]], [[San Pedro de Quemes Municipality|Quemes Municipality]], south east of the [[Salar de Uyuni|Uyuni salt flat]].<ref>[http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/jog/latin_america/sf-19-3-cerro_paruma-bolivia-chile-1999.pdf lib.utexas.edu] Map of the area</ref><ref>[http://www.ine.gob.bo/publicaciones/visorPdf.aspx?Codigo=050902&tipo=1 Quemes Municipality]: population data and map showing Iru Phutunqu between the mountains Bofedal and Yaretal</ref> It is a relatively small peak, lying within the collapse scarp of a debris avalanche from earlier in the [[Holocene]], which was built up by eruptions to fill much of that feature. There are two craters lying at the summit, with the one to the south displaying [[fumarole]]s. In 1995 the peak's first eruption in recorded history occurred in the form of a [[phreatic eruption]].<ref name=gvp/> ==See also== * [[List of volcanoes in Bolivia]] * [[List of volcanoes in Chile]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Iru Phutunqu (Chile-Nor Lipez)}} [[Category:Active volcanoes]] [[Category:Volcanoes of Tarapacá Region]] [[Category:Stratovolcanoes of Chile]] [[Category:Subduction volcanoes]] [[Category:Volcanoes of Potosí Department]] [[Category:Mountains of Chile]] [[Category:Polygenetic volcanoes]] [[Category:Bolivia–Chile border]] [[Category:International mountains of South America]] {{Potosí-geo-stub}} {{Tarapacá-geo-stub}} {{Andean volcanoes}}
